Award.AwardTitle: NRI: Vine Robots: Achieving Locomotion and Construction by Growth

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
In contrast to legged robots inspired by locomotion in animals, this project explores robotic locomotion inspired by plant growth. Specifically, the project creates the foundation for classes of robotic systems that grow in a manner similar to vines. Within its accessible region, a vine robot provides not only sensing, but also a physical conduit -- such as a water hose that grows to a fire, or an oxygen tube that grows to a trapped disaster victim. The project will demonstrate vine-like robots able to configure or weave themselves into three-dimensional objects and structures such as ladders, antennae for communication, and shelters. These novel co-robots aim to improve human safety, health, and well-being at a lower cost than conventional robots achieving similar outcomes. Because of their low cost, vine robots offer exceptional educational opportunities; the project will include creation and testing of inexpensive educational modules for K-12 students.

This work broadens the concept of bio-inspired robots from animals to plants, the concept of locomotion from point-to-point movement to growth. In contrast to traditional terrestrial moving robots that tend to be based on the animal modality of repeated intermittent contacts with a surface, the vine modality begins with a root, harboring power and logic, and extends using growth, increasing permanent contacts throughout the process. This project will demonstrate a soft robot capable of growing over 100 times in length, withstanding being stepped on, extending through gaps a quarter of its height, climbing stairs and vertical walls, and navigating over rough, slippery, sticky and aquatic terrain. The design adopts a bio-inspired strategy of moving material through the core to the tip, allowing the established part of the robotic vine to remain stationary with respect to the environment. A thin-walled tube fills with air as it grows, allowing the vine robot to be initially stored in a small volume at its base, and to extend very large distances when controllably deployed. Mechanical modeling and new design tools will enable the development of task-specific vine robots for search and rescue, reconfigurable communication antennas, and construction. The paradigm of achieving movement and construction through growth will produce new technologies for integrated actuation, sensing, planning, and control; novel principles and software tools for robot design; and humanitarian applications that push the boundaries of collaborative robotics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In nature, growth allows plants to navigate in tightly confined environments and create structures. We have realized this form of movement artificially through pressure-driven eversion of flexible, thin-walled tubes. We call these ?vine robots? due to their movement pattern similar to that of natural vines. When integrated with actuation and sensing, this concept creates soft robots with unprecedented capabilities. The vine robots we developed are capable of growing over 100 times in length, withstanding being stepped on, extending through gaps a quarter of their height, climbing stairs as large as a meter per step, and navigating over rough, slippery, sticky and aquatic terrain, or through tortuous paths. Within its region of growth, a vine robot can provide not only sensing, like traditional mobile robots, but also a physical conduit. The robot can also configure itself into patterns that construct three-dimensional objects and structures.

We have explored a large design space for everting vine robots, discovering tradeoffs in material selection, actuation methods, and placement of sensors and tools. These tradeoffs have led to numerous application-specific implementations. In order to characterize designs and inform best practices for control, we created quasi-static models of growth and retraction, as well as kinematic and force-balance models of steering and environment interaction. Methods for everting vine robot control and planning techniques have been developed to move the robot tip to a target, using a variety of modalities to provide reference inputs to the robot ? ranging from teleoperation to vision-based control to a priori planning based on knowledge of environment geometry. Everting vine robot capabilities include deploying and reconfiguring structures, navigating confined spaces, and applying forces on the environment.

Additionally, the inflated-beam systems used in this project inspired an alternate form of shape change: an untethered, inflated robotic truss, composed of thin-walled inflatable tubes, capable of shape change by continuously relocating its joints while its total edge length remains constant. We call this an ?isoperimetric robot? due to its ability to maintain a constant perimeter (i.e. length of the inflated beam) despite extreme shape change via reconfiguration of the truss.

This work is the result of a collaboration between groups in Mechanical and Electrical Engineering at Stanford University and Mechanical Engineering at University of California at Santa Barbara.

Intellectual Merit: This work has broadened our concept of bio-inspired robots from animals to plants and from point-to-point movement to growth. The ability to achieve movement and construction through growth has produced new technologies for integrated actuation, sensing, planning, and control; principles for robot design; and novel applications that enable new forms of human-robot collaboration. Experiments have evaluated the performance of these technologies from low-level mechanical capabilities to achievable paths and manipulation of the environment. The application domains we have explored, including exploration, electromagnetic communications, inspection, construction, medicine, search and rescue, and environmental monitoring provide insights for next-generation human-centered soft robots. A multi-university and interdisciplinary team with combined expertise in soft robotics, sensing, and human-robot physical interaction has created effective new fundamental techniques as well as an array of functioning robots. 

Broader Impacts: Broader impacts of this project are in the areas of application domains, broadening participation, and education. In terms of applications, we have demonstrated that vine robots can enable accessibility and thus provide increased safety for people. Improved communication and sensing achieved by vine robot-based antennae could have significant economic impact due to the increasing interconnectedness of smart objects (i.e., Internet of Things). The relatively low size and weight of the materials and potential for re-use of a soft robot have implications for the environment. In terms of broadening participation, this project has improved research training and advanced the careers of members of underrepresented groups in engineering. We have provided lab tours and tutorials, demonstrated our robotic technology at public events, mentored high school students, and engaged a diverse population of students in the research. Training under this project has also resulted in two women entering engineering faculty positions. In education, we developed soft robotics courses for students at Stanford University and University of California Santa Barbara ranging from Freshmen to Graduate Students, as well as a short course for 8th-12th grade students through Splash, Stanford?s annual public learning event. Hundreds of students, hobbyists, and researchers around the world have accessed our open-source vine robot website, https://www.vinerobots.org.
